sen.j: 宗尊親王（むねたかしんのう、仁治3年11月22日 (旧暦)（1242年12月15日） - 文永11年8月1日 (旧暦)（1274年9月2日））は、鎌倉幕府6代征夷大将軍で皇族での初めての征夷大将軍。
sen.e: Prince Munetaka (December 15, 1242-September 2, 1274) was the 6th Seii taishogun of the Kamakura Shogunate, also he was the first Imperial Seii taishogun.
Prince Munetaka (December 15, 1242-September 2, 1274) was the 6th Shogun of the Kamakura Shogunate, and the first from the Imperial family.
sen.cmt: "Seii taishogun"→"Shogun" - I think "Shogun" is enough for most English speakers"also he was the first Imperial Seii taishogun"→"and the first from the Imperial family"
sen.e: Imperial Prince Munetaka (December 22, 1242-September 9, 1274) was the 6th Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Kamakura Shogunate, and the first from the Imperial family.
sen.cmt: Shogun→Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians")グレゴリオ歴に変換Imperialを追加しました。

sen.j: 後嵯峨天皇の皇子。
sen.e: He was a son of Emperor Go-Saga.
He was a son of Emperor Go-Saga.
He was a son of Emperor Gosaga.

sen.j: 母は蔵人木工頭平棟基の娘・棟子。
sen.e: His mother, Toshi, was a daughter of TAIRA no Munemoto, the kurodo moku nokami.
His mother, Toshi, was a daughter of TAIRA no Munemoto, the Kurodo Moku no Kami (the head of the imperial archives, construction and lumber supplies.)
sen.cmt: Capitalized first letter of "kurodo moku nokami" and added explanation, though not 100% sure
sen.e: His mother, Toshi, was a daughter of TAIRA no Munemoto, the Kurodo Moku no Kami (the head of the imperial archives, construction and lumber supplies.)

sen.j: 後深草天皇、亀山天皇らの異母兄。
sen.e: Emperor Go-Fukakusa and Emperor Kameyama were his younger brother by a different mother.
Emperor Go-Fukakusa and Emperor Kameyama were his younger brothers by a different mother.
Emperor Gofukakusa and Emperor Kameyama were his younger brothers by a different mother.

sen.j: 前代将軍の藤原頼嗣が京に送還された後の建長4年（1252年）4月に鎌倉に迎えられ、11歳にして征夷大将軍となる。
sen.e: After the former Shogun, FUJIWARA no Yoritsugu was sent back to Kyoto, in April, 1252, he was brought into Kamakura and became a Seii taishogun at the age of 11.
After the previous Shogun, FUJIWARA no Yoritsugu, was sent back to Kyoto, he was brought to Kamakura in April 1252 and made Shogun at the age of 11.
After the previous Shogun, FUJIWARA no Yoritsugu, was sent back to Kyoto, he was brought to Kamakura in May 1252 and made Seii taishogun at the age of 11.
sen.cmt: Shogun→Seii taishogunグレゴリオ歴に変換

sen.j: 親王は後嵯峨天皇の事実上の長子であり、父から寵愛されていたが母方の身分が低いために皇位継承の望みは絶望的であり、後嵯峨天皇は親王の将来を危惧していた。
sen.e: He was virtually the oldest son of Emperor Go-Saga and favored by his father, but it was hopeless to ascend the Imperial throne due to the low status of his mother, thus Emperor Go-Saga worried about his son's future.
Although the oldest son of Emperor Go-Saga and favored by his father, his mother's low status meant he had little chance of ascending the throne, leading the Emperor to worry about his future.
sen.cmt: "He was virtually"→"Although the""but it was hopeless to ascend the Imperial throne due to the low status of his mother"→"his mother's low status meant he had little chance of ascending the throne""thus"→"leading the"Deleted "Go-Saga""worried"→"to worry"deleted "son's"
sen.e: Although the oldest son of Emperor Gosaga and favored by his father, his mother's low status meant he had little chance of ascending the throne, leading the Emperor to worry about his future.

sen.j: その一方で将軍家と摂関家の両方を支配する九条道家（頼嗣の祖父）による幕府政治への介入に危機感を抱いていた執権北条時頼も九条家を政界から排除したいという考えを持っていた。
sen.e: Meanwhile, Tokiyori HOJO, the regent for Shogun (Shikken), wanted to eliminate the Kujo Clan from the political world since he sensed a crisis in the fact that Michiie KUJO (Yoritsugu's grandfather) who controlled both Shogun Family and Regent Family intervened in the Shogunate government.

Meanwhile, the regent for the Shogun, Tokiyori HOJO, sensing a crisis in the fact that Michiie KUJO (Yoritsugu's grandfather) controlled both the Shogun Family and the Regent Families and wanting to eliminate the Kujo Clan from the political world, intervened in the Shogunate government.
sen.cmt: Deleted "(Shikken)"Added "the"Moved "the regent for the Shogun"Moved "a crisis in the fact that Michiie KUJO (Yoritsugu's grandfather) who controlled both Shogun Family and Regent Family"Deleted "who"Made "family" plural"wanted"→"and wanting"Added comma
sen.e: Meanwhile, the regent for the Shogun, Tokiyori HOJO, sensing a crisis in the fact that Michiie KUJO (Yoritsugu's grandfather) controlled both the Shogun family and the Regent families and wanting to eliminate the Kujo clan from the political world, intervened in the Shogunate government.

sen.j: ここにおいて天皇と時頼の思惑が一致したため、「皇族将軍」誕生の運びとなったのである。
sen.e: At this point, the Emperor and Tokiyori shared a mutual interest, which led to the birth of "Imperial Shogun".
sen.cmt: 皇族将軍→Imperial Shogun[定訳不明]
sen.e: At this point, the Emperor and Tokiyori shared a mutual interest, leading to the birth of the "Imperial Shogun".
At this point, the Emperor and Tokiyori shared a mutual interest, leading to the birth of the 'Imperial Shogun.'

sen.j: しかし当時の幕府は既に北条氏による専制体制を整えていたため将軍には何ら権限は無かった。
sen.e: However, the Shogunate has already established a tyranny of the Hojo Clan at the time and the Shogun had no power at all.
However, by this time the Shoguns had already become puppets of the Hojo Clan and the Shogun had no power at all.
sen.cmt: "the Shogunate has already established a"→"by this time the Shoguns had already become puppets"
sen.e: However, by this time the Shoguns had already become puppets of the Hojo clan and the Shogun had no power at all.

sen.j: そのため和歌の創作に打ち込むようになり、歌会を何度もおこなった。
sen.e: Then, he started to put himself into a creation of waka (Japanese poetry) and held Utakai (waka party)
sen.cmt: 和歌→waka[英辞郎 on the WEB]
sen.e: Therefore he threw himself into creating waka poetry and holding Utakai (waka parties.)
sen.cmt: "Then, "→"Therefore""he started to put"→"he threw""a creation of"→"creating"Deleted "Japanese" and bracketsMade "party" pluralAdded full stop
sen.e: Therefore he threw himself into creating waka poetry and holding Utakai (waka parties.)

sen.j: その結果、鎌倉における武家を中心とする歌壇が隆盛を極め、後藤基政・島津忠景ら御家人出身の有能な歌人が輩出された。
sen.e: As a result, the Kadan (waka poetry world) centering on the samurai families in Kamakura flourished and it produced talented Gokenin turned waka poets such as Mototsuna GOTO and Tadakage SHIMAZU.
sen.cmt: 歌壇→Kadan[定訳不明。カッコ書きで説明を入れています。]御家人→Gokenin[定訳不明]
sen.e: As a result, the Kadan (waka poetry world) centering on the samurai families in Kamakura flourished, producing talented Gokenin (shogunate vassals) turned waka poets such as Mototsuna GOTO and Tadakage SHIMAZU.

As a result, the Kadan (waka poetry world) centering on the samurai families in Kamakura flourished, producing talented Gokenin (shogunate vassals) turned waka poets such as Mototsuna GOTO and Tadakage SHIMAZU.

sen.j: 鎌倉歌壇は『続古今和歌集』の撰者の人選にも影響を及ぼし、親王自身も同集の最多入選歌人となっている。
sen.e: The Kadan in Kamakura effected on the selection of compilers of "Shoku kokin wakashu" and the Prince himself was the winningest poet in such wakashu.
The Kamakura Kadan influenced the selection of the compilers of the "Shokukokin Wakashu", with the Prince himself having the most entries.
sen.cmt: Moved "Kamakura"Deleted "in""effected on"→"influenced"Added "the""Shoku kokin wakashu"→"Shokukokin Wakashu""and"→", with""was the winningest poet in such wakashu"→"having the most entries"
sen.e: The Kamakura Kadan influenced the selection of the compilers of the "Shokukokin Wakashu," with the Prince himself having the most entries.

sen.j: 文永3年（1266年）、謀叛の嫌疑をかけられ、将軍を解任されて京に送還される。
sen.e: In 1266, he was dismissed as Shogun and sent back to Kyoto because of a suspicion of rebellion.
In 1266, he was dismissed as Shogun and sent back to Kyoto, being suspected of treason.
sen.cmt: "because of a suspicion of rebellion"→", being suspected of treason"
sen.e: In 1266, he was dismissed as Shogun and sent back to Kyoto, being suspected of treason.

sen.j: 次の将軍は嗣子の惟康親王が就いた。
sen.e: Prince Koreyasu, the son and heir, became the next Shogun.
Prince Koreyasu, his son and heir, became the next Shogun.
Imperial Prince Koreyasu, his son and heir, became the next Shogun.

sen.j: 帰京後は朝廷内に於いて一定の権限を持ち、反北条の貴族と結託し親王への権力集中を図る。
sen.e: After he returned to Kyoto, he had a certain power within the Imperial Court and colluded with anti-Hojo aristocrats to concentrate power in him.
After he returned to Kyoto, he had a certain amount of power within the Imperial Court and colluded with anti-Hojo aristocrats to concentrate power in him.
After he returned to Kyoto, he had a certain amount of power within the Imperial Court and colluded with anti-Hojo aristocrats to concentrate power in him.

sen.j: しかし親北条の貴族らは鎌倉に行動を通報していた。
sen.e: But pro-Hojo aristocrats reported their action.
But pro-Hojo aristocrats reported their activities to the government in Kamakura.
But pro-Hojo aristocrats reported their activities to the government in Kamakura.

sen.j: 更に文永9年（1272年）、後嵯峨法皇の死の直後において「二月騒動（北条教時）」に連座し、出家させられ、佐渡島へ配流された。
sen.e: In addition, he was implicated in "February Riot (Noritoki HOJO was killed)" right after the death of Cloistered Emperor Go Saga. Therefore, he was made to become an ordained monk and banished to Sadogashima Island.
In addition, in 1272, after the death of Cloistered Emperor Go-Saga, he was implicated in the Noritoki HOJO led "February Rebellion," made to enter the priesthood and banished to Sadogashima Island.
sen.cmt: Added "in 1272"Deleted "(Noritoki HOJO was killed)"Added "in the Noritoki HOJO led""Riot"→"Rebellion"Moved "after the death of Cloistered Emperor Go-Saga"Deleted "Therefore, he was""become an ordained monk"→"enter the priesthood"
sen.e: In addition, in 1272, after the death of Cloistered Emperor Gosaga, he was implicated in the Noritoki HOJO led 'February Rebellion,' made to enter the priesthood and banished to Sadogashima Island.

sen.j: 法名：覚恵。
sen.e: His Buddhist name was Kakue (覚恵).
His Buddhist name was Kakue (written 覚恵).
His Buddhist name was Kakue (written 覚恵).

sen.j: また、行証（行勝）。
sen.e: Also, Gyosho (行証 or行勝).
He also used the name Gyosho (written 行証 or 行勝).
He also used the name Gyosho (written 行証 or 行勝).

tit.j: 宗尊親王真跡とされるもの
tit.e: Authentic calligraphy of Imperial Prince Munetaka

sen.j: 有栖川切、催馬楽切、古今集切、神楽歌切などがあり、これ以外にも宗尊親王真跡とされるものは数多く存在する。
sen.e: There are Arisugawa kire, Saibara kire, Kokinshu kire, Kagurauta kire and many others considered to be an authentic calligraphy of Prince Munetaka.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There are many examples of what is considered to be Prince Munetaka's calligraphy including the Arisugawa kire (fragment), the Saibara kire, the Kokinshu kire, and the Kagurauta kire.
sen.cmt: Added definition of "kire"Reworded sentenceAlthough the translator says they split the sentence in two, the original already is two sentences.
sen.e: There are many examples of what is considered to be Prince Munetaka's calligraphy including the Arisugawa kire (fragment), the Saibara kire, the Kokinshu kire, and the Kagurauta kire.

sen.j: だがその多くは、宗尊親王が愛玩あるいは愛好した平安時代の名筆と思われるものが多く含まれ、宗尊親王真跡であるか不明であるものが多いとされる。
sen.e: In fact, many of them are great calligraphy from Heian Period that he loved and it is unclear which is Prince Munetaka's authentic calligraphy.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In fact, many of them are classic examples of the Prince's much-loved Heian Period calligraphy and it is unclear which are Prince Munetaka's authentic calligraphy.
sen.cmt: "great"→"classic examples"Moved "Heian Period"Deleted "from""that he loved"→"the Prince's much-loved""is"→"are"
sen.e: In fact, many of them are classic examples of the Prince's much-loved Heian Period calligraphy and it is unclear which are Imperial Prince Munetaka's authentic calligraphy.

sen.j: しかし名筆家であるという評価は揺るがない。
sen.e: However, his reputation as a great calligraphy is unchallenged.
However, his reputation as a great calligrapher is unchallenged.
However, his reputation as a great calligrapher is unchallenged.

tit.e: Chronology of Government Posts and Ranks
Chronology of Government Posts and Ranks
Chronology of Government Posts and Ranks

sen.j: ※日付＝旧暦
sen.e: Lunar calendar used for the dates.
Lunar calendar used for dates.
Lunar calendar used for dates.

sen.j: 寛元2年（1244年）1月28日、立親王。
sen.e: January 28, 1244, named Prince by the Emperor.
sen.cmt: 立親王を親王宣下と考えました。
sen.e: January 28, 1244, named Prince by the Emperor.
January 28, 1244: Named Prince by the Emperor.
sen.cmt: 旧暦を新暦に年月日：の形にしました。

sen.j: 建長4年（1252年）1月8日、元服。
sen.e: January 8, 1252, a coming-of-age ceremony.
January 8, 1252, Coming-of-age Ceremony.
January 8, 1252: Coming-of-age Ceremony.

sen.j: 三品に叙せらる。
sen.e: Given the rank of Sanbon.
Given the rank of Sanbon, the third rank for Princes.
Given the rank of Sanbon, the third rank for Princes.

sen.j: 4月1日、征夷大将軍宣下。
sen.e: April 1, named Seii taishogun by the Emperor.
April 1, named Shogun by the Emperor.
April 1: Named Seii taishogun by the Emperor.

sen.j: 文永2年（1265年）9月17日、一品に昇叙し、中務卿に任官。
sen.e: September 17, 1265, promoted to the rank of Ippon and assumed the position of Nakatsukasakyo.
September 17, 1265, promoted to the rank of Ippon, the highest rank for Princes, and made head of the Ministry of the Center.
sen.cmt: Added explanation of "Ippon""assumed the position of Nakatsukasakyo"→"made head of the Ministry of the Center"
sen.e: September 17, 1265: Promoted to the rank of Ippon, the highest rank for Princes, and made Nakatsukasa-kyo (Minister of the Ministry of Central Affairs).
sen.cmt: 旧暦を新暦に中務卿→Nakatsukasa-kyo (Minister of the Ministry of Central Affairs)

sen.j: 文永3年（1266年）7月20日、征夷大将軍辞職。
sen.e: July 20, 1266, resigned from the position of Seii taishogun.
July 20, 1266, resigned from the position of Shogun.
July 20, 1266: Resigned from the position of Seii taishogun.
